summary: we have always kinda hated on Fury for not telling the Avengers about his plans throughout the series but if you think about it...
body:
we have always kinda hated on Fury for not telling the Avengers about his plans throughout the series but if you think about it his trust issues are completely justified now; he never knew if or when some new alien would come around and he didn’t know if they could transform to look and sound just like humans down to the DNA and he didn’t know if they would be good or bad.

the skrull could turn their DNA to match someone else’s- there was almost no way of knowing whether one member or all members of the Avengers were some form of alien race that could look and sound just like them with evil intentions. and because there DNA would match, it would make sense for them to have the same powers as the real Avengers.

idk man. i just feel like we gave him a lot of hate for keeping secrets from the Avengers - the freaking team he put together like i totally understand where we came from - but now i think it’s justified

summary: Stuck in the middle with you, some thoughts on “Captain Marvel”
body:
Stuck in the middle with you, some thoughts on “Captain Marvel”

Captain Marvel is Marvel Studio’s “Batman v. Superman”: an overstuffed, messy film with two separate plot lines that beg for their own separate narratives. Like BvS, “Captain Marvel” isn’t trying to tell a compelling story, but rather fill in a narrative gap left by last year’s “Avengers: Infinity War” (or in BvS’s case, get us to “Justice League”). “Captain Marvel” isn’t a terrible film, just a very misguided one.

All of the film’s problem stem from the unfortunate reality that this story is simply Infinity War’s intermission and nothing more. It’s going through the motions writ large. We teased her at the end of Infinity War, and now we got two hours plus to take Carol Danvers on the same hero’s journey we took Captain America, Iron Man, and Thor through across three solo films. You know, actually, Marvel probably didn’t need three films to develop a character like Steve Rogers. This isn’t a Ingmar Bergman movie. Honestly, we knew everything we needed to know about Captain America after the first one. And yet none of those solo films felt as bloated and weird as “Captain Marvel”. Previous Marvel Studios offerings had the luxury of time, but poor Carol Danvers does not. Not only does she have to be the strong female that does whatever it takes to make it in a man’s world, she also has to resolve a centuries long war between the Skrulls and the Kree, and if that wasn’t enough, she also has to rediscover her past and master her powers, and so on.

It’s a damn shame, too, because Carol is an interesting character and Brie Larson shows us flashes of that throughout the film. She’s strong willed, genuine, thrill seeking, and funny. I only wish she got some breathing room to show us more. I wanted more Carol and less fight scenes. I wanted to actually get to know this character and her life on earth. I wanted to see her going through basic training and trying to get her wings in the air force in real time instead of through flashbacks. I wanted to see her relationship with her best friend Maria. I wanted to see all that stuff that pretentious people call “character development”. Tony Stark got it; why not Carol Danvers?

Because “Captain Marvel” isn’t a Marvel Studios solo film with a female lead, it’s an interlude. It’s a mandatory stop on the way to “Avengers: Endgame”.

Carol deserves better.

What if we see him in the soul stone or when he comes back saying “flerckin”. You know how he did in captain marvel? I think it would be hilarious.

blog.description:
mel. 24. ravenclaw. wampus. browncoat. s.h.i.e.l.d. erudite. avenger. doctor who. merlin. harry potter. game of thrones. lord of the rings. the avengers. the walking dead. star trek. firefly. 12 monkeys. shadowhunters. reign. humans. covert affairs. avatar the last airbender. legend of korra. psych. nikita. dollhouse. agent carter. supergirl. true blood. star wars. the flash. arrow. the 1oo. dark matter. from dusk till dawn. the punisher. timeless. the rain. criminal minds.

~~~

Books: song of the lioness. the immortals. throne of glass. the mortal instruments.the thief. gallagher girls. strange angels. devil's kiss. vampire academy. maximum ride. bloodlines. heist society. percy jackson. harry potter.

~~~

Currently Reading: Tower of Dawn

~~~

Currently Crying Over: Rogue One. Arrow. Timeless. The Rain. INFINITY WAR. Kingdom of Ash. GARCIA FUCKING FLYNN. endgame....don't even look at me or I'll cry.

~~~

summary: So, why didn’t you like captain marvel?
question: So, why didn’t you like captain marvel?
answer:
Obviously, spoilers under the cut 

My problems with this movie are inconsistencies and holes in the plot.
The Tesseract, for a start. At the end of Captain America - the first avenger we see Howard Stark collect the bright cube from the bottom of the ocean while looking for Steve. Howard, being one of the founders of SHIELD, has me thinking the cube has been in their hands since 1949 ca. So, how did Mar-Vell get the tesseract so she could craft the engine? Did she steal it? Did she borrow it from SHIELD?
Talking about the engine… In the scene where the plane crashed, we see Mar-Vell dead, Carol’s near the engine (which is powered by the tesseract) and said crashed plane and Yon-Rogg approaching. At this point, Carol shoots the engine, which explosion hits her. Now, I’ve got two problems with this scene. The blast hits her and only her and she survives. Now, I can excuse the fact that it’s a movie based on a comic book so the laws of physics might not apply - but not really. What I can’t make peace with is the fact that Carol -only a human being- is hit by an explosion caused by the same Tesseract used by Red Skull in the first captain america movie reduced people into atoms. What would’ve made sense was to make Carol half human - half kree just like in the comics, maybe making Mar-Vell herself her own mother since we don’t see Carol’s actual mother in the movie anyways. 
About Mar-Vell, getting past the how-did-she-get-the-tesseract bit: she has her own spaceship orbiting around the earth where she studies the tesseract and its energy without the airforce knowing? I mean, I don’t think she got past the airforce committee and got straight to SHIELD’s to borrow the thing and save the Skrulls. Especially when we see Nick Fury and the USAF employers not being nice to each other… It’s confusing.
What about Goose (who I really wished they’d call chewie as in the comics)? In the comics this cat is basically the Lucky to Clint, the Liho to Nat, so I thought that in the end Carol would keep her. But… nope! We see her with Fury. Which doesn’t make sense since he could’ve easily summoned her during the battle of New York. 
How did Marvel HQ let these things slip I don’t know, they’re pretty big…

Overall it’s an okay movie, not as bad as Thor 2 but not as good as Cap 2. In my opinion, they focused too much on some details and explanations that made it a bit confusing. Brie Larson didn’t really shine, at some points I found Carol’s behaviour a bit too serious for the general lighter or not that serious mood of the scenes. In most bits of the movie I found the main focus was “look at this fabulous new superhero! She’s a woman! She’s super powerful!” rather than the actual plot. Like I said, it wasn’t a bad movie it just needed to be a little bit… more. Everything was rather bland, to be honest. It’s not a film I’d recommend, but it has its chances.

The Tesseract, for a start. At the end of Captain America - the first avenger we see Howard Stark collect the bright cube from the bottom of the ocean while looking for Steve. Howard, being one of the founders of SHIELD, has me thinking the cube has been in their hands since 1949 ca. So, how did Mar-Vell get the tesseract so she could craft the engine? Did she steal it? Did she borrow it from SHIELD?
Talking about the engine… In the scene where the plane crashed, we see Mar-Vell dead, Carol’s near the engine (which is powered by the tesseract) and said crashed plane and Yon-Rogg approaching. At this point, Carol shoots the engine, which explosion hits her. Now, I’ve got two problems with this scene. The blast hits her and only her and she survives. Now, I can excuse the fact that it’s a movie based on a comic book so the laws of physics might not apply - but not really. What I can’t make peace with is the fact that Carol -only a human being- is hit by an explosion caused by the same Tesseract used by Red Skull in the first captain america movie reduced people into atoms. What would’ve made sense was to make Carol half human - half kree just like in the comics, maybe making Mar-Vell herself her own mother since we don’t see Carol’s actual mother in the movie anyways. 
About Mar-Vell, getting past the how-did-she-get-the-tesseract bit: she has her own spaceship orbiting around the earth where she studies the tesseract and its energy without the airforce knowing? I mean, I don’t think she got past the airforce committee and got straight to SHIELD’s to borrow the thing and save the Skrulls. Especially when we see Nick Fury and the USAF employers not being nice to each other… It’s confusing.

But… nope! We see her with Fury. Which doesn’t make sense since he could’ve easily summoned her during the battle of New York.
